item.title: Trends of Road Traffic Accidents - April 2024
item.dc:creator: Daniel Eurien
item.description:
Note

This blog utilizes accident data sourced from daily newspapers. It does not aim to substitute or dispute official police traffic reports. Instead, it aims to complement the existing narrative by providing additional context to the road traffic accident reports disseminated by the media. As such, any interpretation of these findings should be done with this context in mind.This monthly blog therefore seeks to provide patterns of major accidents on highways, given that the majority of such incidents are covered by the media. The process of data extraction can be found in separate blog ‘Process of data aquisition and model building’.

Data Completeness

We only considered variables with >70% completeness for quantitative analysis. Meanwhile, variables with more than 30% missing data were analyzed qualitatively using natural language processing techniques, including word cloud analysis.

Trend in Road Traffic Accidents

Trend of Total Accidents Reported in Newspapers, 2021-2024

The number of highway accidents reported in newspapers in the first one-third of 2024 is already one-third of the average over the past 3 years from 2021-2023, indicating a similar elevated trajectory in 2024.

Trend of Total Accidents by Month

There is an overall spike in the number of accidents reported in May followed by November to December period.

Trend of Total Accidents Reported by Month Faceted by Year

There is a consistent marginal increase in road accidents reported by newspapers in May in all 3 years between 2021 to 2023. However, this report only covers data up to April.

Total Number of Accidents Rported by Month by Type of Car Involved

Trucks registered the highest number of accidents consistent reported by newspapers over the 12 months of year.

Total Number of Accidents Rported by Month by Type of Car Involved Faceted by Year

Trucks registered the highest number of accidents consistent reported by newspapers over the 12 months of the period 2021 to 2023, including the first quarter of 2024.

Time Analysis

Total Number of Accidents Reported by Time of Occurrence

The highest proportion of accidents reported happened at 6 am in the morning.

Total Number of Accidents Reported by Time of Occurence by car type

Accidents occured most at 6am, this was consistent for most of the car types. Trucks had the highest number of road crushes happening at 6 am in the morning followed by Private cars

Total Number of Accidents by month and accident type

Most accidents happened at 6 am in the morning with cars overturning being the commonest type of accident. Atleast all accident type registered atleast 1 accident at 6 am in the morning.

Total Number of Accidents by month and accident type over the three years

Generally, most accidents happened at 6 am in the morning. Cars overturning was the most type of accident reported at 6 am over the 3 years from 2021 to 2023, however, this has not been observed in 2024.

Total Number of Accidents by type and time of day

Generally most head on collisions and cars ramming onto stationary trucks happened at night

Total Number of Accidents by day of week

Generally more road crushed were reported on Monday and Tuesday, with the least number of road crushes reported on a Saturday.

Total Number of Accidents by day of week and time of day

Most road crushes reported by newspapers occured on a Monday monrning.

Total Number of Accidents by day of week over the three years

Total Number of Accidents by day of week and time of day over the three years

The prevalent occurrence of road crushes at 6 am in the morning is consistent over the three years under study. However, the consistency in days is only true on Monday mornings and spread ramdomly throught the days of the week when compared over the three years from 2021 to 2023, however, this has not yet been observed in 2024.

Summary

  1. Elevated accident trend: The number of highway accidents reported in newspapers in the first quarter of 2024 is already one-third of the average over the past 3 years, indicating a similar elevated trajectory in 2024.
  2. Seasonal spikes: There are overall spikes in the number of accidents reported, with increases in May and the November-December period.
  3. High truck involvement: Trucks consistently registered the highest number of accidents reported by newspapers over the 12-month period and across the 2021-2023 years.
  4. Morning peak: The highest proportion of accidents occurred at 6 am, with trucks being the vehicle type most involved in crashes at this time.
  5. Weekly patterns: More accidents were reported on Mondays and Tuesdays, with the least on Saturdays. The 6 am peak on Mondays was a consistent trend across the 2021-2023 period.

item.title: Process of data aquisition and model building
item.dc:creator: Daniel Eurien
item.description:
Introduction

Road traffic accidents accidents in Uganda pose a significant challenge, with a high number of fatalities reported every week. The Uganda police issues a weekly crime report that includes data on road crashes. However, these reports often lack the necessary details to fully understand the nature and severity of the accidents. This blog aims to use publicly available unstructured data from newspaper articles to get a nuanced picture of what, when, and critical aspects of road accidents to identify hot-spots for targeted actions to enhance road safety.

{#fig-police report}

Opportunity of using Artificial Intelligence(AI) to Extract Newspaper Articles

Natural Language Processing (NLP), a sub-field of Artificial Intelligence, offers an exciting opportunity to extract structured data from text to create a structured database. NLP can be trained to understand human language, enabling the extraction of valuable information from newspaper articles for further analysis. To delve deeper into NLP, you can read more about it in the article Natural Language Processing. In my own exploration of NLP, I utilized its capabilities by training a custom entity recognition model. This model allowed me to extract specific data from newspaper articles, making it easier to analyze and derive insights. To learn more about Named Entity Recognition (NER), which is a fundamental technique in NLP, you can refer to the article Named Entity Recognition.

Process of Data Aquisition and Model Training

Custom NER model training

The schemer shows the nine step process of data aquisition and model training.

How Named Entity Recognition Works

NER uses pretrained Large Language Models(LLMs) that are trained on universal entites as shown in the schemer below. However, since LLMs are trained on general corpus of text that may include Wikipedia, it may perform poorly on specific tasks like identifying road traffic variables in a country like Uganda. Becuase of this limitation, I therefore customised the pretrained LLM by training it using a corpus of annotated Ugandan newspaper articles reporting accidents. For more information on LLMs, please refer to LLMs.

{#fig-ner process}

Process of annotation to fine tune the LLM

I used a free online annotation tool called tecoholic to annotate 21 variables of interest using 150 newspaper articles that reported road traffic accidents in 2021. The trained model was the used to extract key variables from 300 newspaper articles from 2021 to 2023

Training Results

Performance of the model

The model performed well on unseen newspaper articles averaging 70% performance across all metrics:

  1. ENTS_P: Precision score for named entities: measures the proportion of correctly identified named entities out of all predicted named entities. Higher values indicate better precision.

  2. ENTS_R: Recall score for named entities: Recall measures the proportion of correctly identified named entities out of all actual named entities. Higher values indicate better recall.

  3. ENTS_F: F1 score for named entities: measure of the model’s accuracy in identifying named entities, considering both precision and recall. Higher values indicate better performance.

  4. SCORE: Represents an overall score: that combines multiple metrics to evaluate the performance of the NER pipeline. Higher values indicate better overall performance.

Model deployment

The final process was deployement of the model to 300 newspaper articles on road traffic accidents to obtain a structured dataset. ::: {layout-ncol=“1”} :::

Conclusion

Results from the analysis

To view the results from this analysis, please refer to a separate blog on

Implications

The study’s insights on Named Entity Recognition (NER) performance in text mining have broad implications across various applications:

  1. Information Extraction: Accurate NER enhances information extraction from unstructured text, benefiting tasks like news summarization, document analysis, and knowledge graph construction.

  2. Knowledge Discovery: NER facilitates knowledge discovery by identifying and categorizing entities, supporting tasks such as trend analysis, market research, and social network analysis.

  3. Search and Recommendation Systems: Integrating NER improves search and recommendation system accuracy by understanding user queries or preferences and providing targeted results.

  4. Text Classification and Sentiment Analysis: NER contributes to text classification and sentiment analysis by identifying important entities, leading to more precise insights from text data.

  5. Natural Language Understanding and Conversational AI: NER enhances natural language understanding and conversational AI systems by recognizing entities in user input, enabling better context understanding and response generation.

  6. Data Integration and Linkage: NER aids data integration and linkage by identifying entities across datasets, supporting tasks like data harmonization and entity resolution for a unified data view.

  7. NER as a Service: The study’s findings may lead to NER-as-a-service offerings, enabling organizations to leverage pre-trained NER models or APIs for streamlined integration into various systems and workflows.
